name: Blood Python
description: It is a robust snake with a base color ranging from rusty to orange shades, though the intensity and hue vary individually. Its pattern of irregular ochre spots and stripes covers nearly the entire body, with dark brown to black speckles possible on the sides. The belly is white, the head gray, with a dark stripe running behind the eye.
food_note: Small fish, tadpoles, insects and their larvae
image_alt: Blood Python, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Length 100–150 (200) cm, with one-fifth being the tail; weight 6–12 kg
reproduction: Females lay 5–20 elongated eggs; incubation lasts about 65 days
attractions: It belongs to the family of the reticulated python, differing by its shorter tail and, notably, its rusty coloration in adulthood. It is active at dusk and night, hunting during these times. Females coil around their eggs, guarding and warming them with special body twitches. In some parts of its range, it has adapted to landscape changes, colonizing oil palm plantations where it preys on rodents.
